content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="P C l 3"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) In the box below, draw the complete Lewis electron-dot diagram for <math alttext="P C l 3"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="P C l 3"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) In the box below, draw the complete Lewis electron-dot diagram for <math alttext="P C l 3"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) What is the shape of the <math alttext="P C l 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule?

<math alttext="P C l 3 gas, plus C l 2 gas, is in equilibrium with P C l 5 gas. K sub c equals 0.11"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mo>â‡„</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.11</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

A <math alttext="0.60 mole"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.60</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="P C l 3 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and a <math alttext="0.70 mole"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="C l 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are placed in a previously evacuated <math alttext="1.0 liter"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> rigid container, and the reaction represented above takes place. At equilibrium, the concentration of <math alttext="P C l 5 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container is <math alttext="0.040 molar"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.040</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) On the graph above, carefully draw three curves, one for each of the three gases. The curves must show how the concentration of each of the three gases changes as equilibrium is established. Label each curve with the formula of the gas.
(d) Explain how the slopes of the curves at equilibrium can be used to show that the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are the same at equilibrium.
(e) As the reaction occurs at constant temperature, does the pressure inside the container increase, decrease, or remain the same? Explain.

Another mixture of <math alttext="P C l 3 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="C l 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="P C l 5 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is at equilibrium at a different temperature in a different vessel. The system at equilibrium is represented by the following box on the left. Then the volume of the vessel is decreased. The box in the middle represents the system before equilibrium is reestablished at the same temperature.

(f) In the box above on the right, draw an appropriate number of each type of molecule to represent a possible new equilibrium.

skill.text: 3.A: Represent chemical phenomena using appropriate graphing techniques, including correct scale and units.
